meanings.def: developing, growing, etc. gradually and in an even and regular way
examples: We've had five years of steady economic growth.
The last decade has seen a steady decline in the number of birds nesting here.
There has been a gradual but steady increase in prices.
We are making slow but steady progress.
The castle receives a steady stream of visitors.
There seemed to be a steady flow of customers all day.
His breathing was steady.
a steady job/income
She drove at a steady 50 mph.
They set off at a steady pace.
a steady boyfriend/girlfriend (= with whom you have a serious relationship or one that has lasted a long time)
to have a steady relationship
They wanted me to get a steady job.
The new position would provide him with a steady income.
She's got a steady boyfriend.
Profits before tax remained steady at £91m.

meanings.def: fixed in a place or position, supported or balanced; controlled and not shaking or likely to fall down
examples: He held the boat steady as she got in.
I met his steady gaze.
Such fine work requires a good eye and a steady hand.
She’s not very steady on her feet these days.
Hold the ladder steady!
She opened the letter with hands that were not quite steady.

meanings.def: sensible; who can be relied on
what you say to tell people to start a race
extremely steady and calm; that you can rely on

idioms.def: what you say to tell people to start a race
extremely steady and calm; that you can rely on

related: at a fast, good, steady, etc. clip

meanings.def: to stop yourself/somebody/something from moving, shaking or falling; to stop moving, shaking or falling
examples: She steadied herself against the wall.
The lift rocked slightly, steadied, and the doors opened.

meanings.def: to stop changing and become regular again
examples: Her heartbeat steadied.
steady against something The pound steadied against the dollar.
He took a few deep breaths to steady his nerves.

meanings.def: in a way that is steady and does not change or shake
examples: In trading today the dollar held steady against the yen.
Share prices have held steady over the last few days.
Inflation seems to be holding steady.

meanings.def: to have a romantic or sexual relationship with somebody, in which you see the other person regularly
examples: They’ve been going steady for a year now.

idioms.def: to have a romantic or sexual relationship with somebody, in which you see the other person regularly
examples: They’ve been going steady for a year now.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to be careful about what they are saying or doing, for example because it is extreme or not appropriate
examples: Steady on! You can't say things like that about somebody you've never met.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to be careful
examples: Steady! Don't fall off.
